reviewText:
X-note is a game I have been following since the demo was released on Zeiva's deviantART page some number of years ago (the demo is also available for free off of Zeiva inc's webpage: http://www.zeiva.net/). Seeing the full game now available on Steam was exciting and I was not disappointed.

The graphics, the characters in particular, were all very pretty and cohesive in style.  Atmospherically, the combination of horror themes, music and lighting were done well and used sparingly to create dramatic effect during those scenes.  The music was mixed frequently to help break the monotony of background sounds on a loop; plus the music was better than anticipated going into the game.  As a note, there is no audio for the dialogue and narration.

Gameplay wise, the game relies on both choices and mini games which boost stats.  There are only 3 stats and only one can be trained via mini game per day.  The mini games are doable without being overly difficult for the casual player.  If you were to get a bad ending due to stats, the game gives helpful advice as to what to do for next time so it eliminates the need to go hunting online for a walkthrough.  There are 9 different endings, and each ending adds something to the overarching storyline.  My only critic of the game is that each path is relatively short and can be completed in roughly an hour.  However, the story is interesting, emotional and I look forward to the sequel Area-X.


One nice thing to note is that anyone who has already purchased this game off of Zeiva inc's website may obtain a free steam code by e-mailing them the e-mail address that they purchased the game with.  It's hard to think of any other company that would do this.

reviewText:
This is an all around good game. The art is fantastic and the music is nice. Well, the music is good, but it also sort of fades into the background while playing. The story is interesting and changes depending on the route you're taking making each play through less same-y.

When it comes to playing the game it's both straight forward and not at the same time. There's a reason there are guides[www.zeiva.net] on the creator website and it's because you'll probably get only bad endings without them. They're official and mostly spoiler free, doing little but say what choices to make and what skills to raise by when.

The actual gameplay is simple, every day you play a minigame to raise one of three psychic abilities and every so often you pick between choices, standard visual novel stuff. The minigames start off simple and grow harder as the story progresses, but you can save before trying, and fail a few times in a row before you have to either reload a save or fail for the day.

One thing that is fairly lacking is how the abilities play into the game. You have to have certain abilities at certain levels to proceed and each love interest (Yuon, Oure, and Anon) has one that is extra important to their route. Otherwise, they aren't tied to the game. Skill level doesn't change dialogue, add extra scenes (except one additional scene after each LI's good ending), or require you to actually use them. Fairly anticlimactic really.

As I said before, there are three love interests: Yuon, Oure, and Anon. I've gone through each of their routes, obtaining both their good and bad endings. I really enjoy all of them and recommend saving Anon for last. While you have to go through the same basic story to get through each route, the overall story you see changes a lot depending upon the route you're taking. It's both good and bad that you can't skip through already seen text, as there's little to the game that is superfulous and not plot related. However, going on your fourth time through it can get a little annoying with reading the stuff you just read thirty minutes ago again.

To simplify things I'd make three saves on Day 5, before making any choice, one for each LI (preferably one save per page), then again at the beginning of Chapter 5 to let you go for both their good or bad endings. And really, use the guides[www.zeiva.net]. Do yourself a favor.

reviewText: This otome visual novel feature a female protagonist Essi who is an ordinary schoolgirl with latent supernatural powers. One day, she was approached by Yuon to study at Xen Institute and to investigate the deaths of her mother and several of the Institute's staff under mysterious circumstances. Along the way, Essi has to train and develop her latent powers through 3 different minigames, interact with a mysterious ally Rexus and develop a romance ending with Yuon who is the current director at the Institute, Oure who appears to be a regular student who frequently hangs out at a corridor inside the Institute or with Anon who appears to be the local computer expert within the Institute. The game has up to 15 save slots to enable quicker replays to reach a different romance ending or to see an alternative bad ending, in-game tips to guide the player to progress further to reach a better ending upon reaching a bad ending and a password system to instantly jump straight into a particular chapter with a certain storyline branch and skilltree progress or to unlock a special CG and soundtrack gallery.\n\nSoundtracks and overall game presentation are decent, it would have been nice if the game allows the take screenshot button on Steam to work. Recommended when at sale or in a bundle offer as all 9 endings can be reached and the entire game's unlockable CG and extra content at gallery can be completed in less than 10 hours.

reviewText:
A mediocre 2-5 hour mystery VN (high variation in time based on pursuing multiple endings).

Where this VN does best is that it manages to work in some neat little surprises in how all of the dots connect together in such a short time frame. I definitely enjoyed the manner in which the story was exposed to the reader.

I felt the artwork was a lot less lazy in X-Note than what I've seen from many other VNs of the same caliber. Kudos to the artist offering up far more assets than would be considered the minimum.

Most of the other assets fit well into the passable category. For such a small VN, I still ended up finding the music mildly redundant. The engine could be better with offering better skip options through lengthy dialogs (pretty necessary for multi-path VNs, really) and options for scrolling up through previous dialog in case you missed something.

The mini-games are fairly petty, but I can't say that they detracted from my experience much.

The thing I hated the most about X-Note, are how the fail-states are constructed. There are 3 different character skills that you can upgrade, and those need to be at certain levels at certain milestones. There is very rarely any logic associated with why you need those skills to be at those milestones. Oh, you decided to shoot me in the gut because my clairvoyance skill wasn't high enough; thanks, game. The positive value of this unfairness is that you get to actually properly experience all the endings - whenever you get a bad ending, the game gives you tips on what you need to do to get the good ending.

The ultimate reason for this review being negative is the base price-tag of $20. Nobody in their right mind should pay more than $10 for this, and my personal cutoff point would be around $5.

This is not my first ever visual novel, however it is the most recent one I've played in a long time.

The music is pretty good, and the art is absolutely fantastic. Definitely top quality in those realms.
The story is fairly interesting, and it kept me entertained, but only the first time through, as I was trying for different endings I was speeding through the dialog.

There is a hilarious parady of a particular O/S that is quite funny imo.

My biggest complaint is with the 'advancement' system. There are specific requirements you need to have obtained to 'pass' certain chapters and continue the story, however, the reasoning behind those requirements just don't exist and are never mentioned.

Without giving anything away, imagine you need a 6 out of 10 strength to stop a heavy bookshelf from crushing you, but unfortunately you only have a 5... so you die. Fair, I get it. With a six you live... Fine. Makes sense. What doesn't make sense is lets say you need a 6 strength to pass this chapter, and if you don't have it, you can't pick the lock of the door and get caught by an evil gerbil and die. Nonsense? I think so. And that is part of what irritated me with X-Note.

The requirements didn't make sense.

However, I did indeed enjoy playing the game, once I managed to just ignore the requirements and put sanity on hold.

I'm still working on getting other endings, so in that sense, I'm still playing.

I'd have to give it a 7/10, worth getting, but definitely not at full price. Wait for a bundle or a major discount.

reviewText:
If you’re interested in this game then chances you are both someone who likes visual novels, and someone who likes a mystery story.  Unfortunately this game is good at neither.  I was put off by the Mary Sue vibe in the beginning of the story where the main protagonists are doing things and interacting with other characters without providing relevant context to the reader.  The writing is bland, generic, and feels like a middle school project and should not be read as a piece of entertainment.  The software lacks many common features found in visual novels: for example, hold ctrl to skip dialogs, an internal volume controller to make the bgm not blasting loud, etc.

Anyway, this game is not worth your time even if you manage to get it for free.

reviewText:
One Sentence Summary- If you like graphical novels, you'll probably like his game.

If you are not familiar with them, you may like it, you may not. All in all, the game plays as if it is 80% graphical novel, and 20% like an actual game. First, let me say the positives:

+Nice Artwork
+Fun characters
+Appropriate Music
+Very much like a Japanese Anime (if you like that)
+Is mostly based upon a mystery, but has some romance elements
+Thankfully, as far as I can tell, the romance elements are fairly clean and innocent.
+Multiple Endings

-Doesn't seem like the choices you make alter the story very much.
-You play as a teenage girl in a game with some romance elements (a minus if you're a guy)
-The game ends very abruptly if you get the bad ending, which I did.
-Unless you have some foreknowledge, most people will have to start over to get past chapter 4 (I think). This should be optional to get a better ending, but it feels punishing to make you start over from the beginning in order to progress further.

As to whether or not I recommend this game, I'm on the fence. If you like this type of game, get it on sale. If not, get something else. However, the game is fairly good for what it is, so I'll give it a thumb up.

reviewText:
Ah, X-note. I started playing this game because of Area-X, and before I played Rexus' path I realized I didn't want to be spoiled for X-note and thus downloaded it to play.

My recommendation for doing the routes: Yuon - Oure - Anon. Even Zeiva recommends doing Yuon's route before Anon's. The way I see this: Yuon's route establishes the game to an ending; Oure's route changes a few things in Yuon's route (kind of like a what if, but don't worry, doesn't change the plot), while Anon's route answers quite a lot of questions and mysteries that this game contains.

What I liked:
- mini-games were related to the story plot
- the artwork - anyone who likes Japanese artwork will like this one
- the story plot was nice, although interestingly you don't find out the mysteries all in one path (perhaps a smart move by Zeiva to get people to replay routes), although  you don't find out everything, like Emma's death - was it really caused by Scid? Or did Loil lie and it was really caused by him? Or was there a bigger mystery behind it? We'll perhaps never know
- the characters, while at first glance look similar to otome archetypes, are actually deconstructed (to some extent) in their routes, especially Oure and Anon. Much props to this, but then since Zeiva had intended to parody the archetypes in the first place it's really not that big of a surprise. Special mention goes to Anon; I didn't think much of him initially, and even during Yuon and Oure's paths, but his path certainly surprised me. A pleasant surprise, don't worry. Anon is easily the most interesting and complex character in the whole game, and I say this as an Oure fan. I shudder at how much he must have suffered when he was younger - from witnessing war, to being accused of nasty things, to being bullied, to accidentally 'murder' his best and only friend, and when he didn't use his powers he still caused pain. No wonder he tried to commit suicide - at the age of six. Also, when Essi was in his mind and cried that it was really dark and painful, you have to wonder just what kind of scars he had, and how much he must have been suffering his whole life. Considering the implications that he would have committed suicide if Essi didn't pursue him, he made for an ultimately tragic character. While Oure is described as the ultimate victim of the game, which I don't disagree, Anon is a big victim in this game as well. Arguably, they all are victims of circumstances in ways.
- the music was appropriate

What I disliked:
- the minigames were somewhat difficult when you try to max out the stats, and it gets ever more tedious and frustrating when you replay routes to see other endings. Much as I like how the minigames are integrated into the story plot, it also makes me grind my teeth to have to play Psychokinesis III for the Xth time (pun not intended). Although, with the save/load function, it does make it easier - I shudder for those that played V1 of this game.
- Loil.  As a villain, I expected more from him; yes, the game does establish him as the Big Bad, and a psychopath (sociopath?) who has no qualms to use anybody and everybody to satisfy his own goals and desires. That being said, he still kind of fell flat compared to the main characters (I'm not comparing him to the secondary characters, he should be more fleshed out as the villain); why did he do what he did? Anon's path does answer this to some extent, but it's not enough. We never really see why Loil did what he did. Another peeve is how he basically gets away with everything except in Anon's bad ending, and even then I didn't like it (poor Essi). Since this game isn't all that realistic in the first place, Loil should have been served what he deserved, but he wasn't, and furthermore, the times where he just retreated quickly after being confronted by Essi (and others) was just weird - he would bow down in defeat so easily? Considering how far he went to remove 'obstacles' in his path, this seemed rather OOC for him (could be argued that because he was up against psychics, which made him realize he was no match for them, but even that feels too flimsy - Zeiva could have had him fight harder, but they didn't). All in all, Loil was a pretty unsatisfying villain, which I'm chalking up to because Anon was intended to be the villain, Loil wasn't fleshed out that well than if Anon had remained the villain.

All in all, while I did enjoy X-note, I still found Area-X to be superior. And I'm saying this as someone who has only played 2 routes in Area-X (Belph and Yuras), while I've completed all 9 endings for this game. This isn't a bad thing; Area-X being newer and better, means that Zeiva is improving with time, which is always a good thing. Though, that being said, it remains a debate whether getting this game at $20 is worth it. My opinion? If you enjoy OELVN, and otome games (but beware that while romance is an aspect, it isn't as overwhelming as other otome VNs, like those of Voltage and NTT Solmare, for instance), and mystery and paranormal aspects, then get this; but if you're on a budget, you might want to consider other offerings.
